On Thu, Oct 16, 2=
008 at 05:36, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
> Thanks Ken and Matt. Thi=
s is really good information, especially learning
> what rules of thumb you=
 are operating by.
>
> So, out of curiosity, if you do have the luxury of a=
 larger population size
> (presumably due to a problem with a quick fitness=
 evaluation), where do you
> recommend investing? More species, or larger s=
pecies?
>
> Is it better to have 100 species of size 30, or 10 species of s=
ize 300?
>
> I am sure this too depends on the problem, but I would be inte=
rested in
> hearing what people have found tends to work (or, at least, wha=
t they tend
> to do).
>
> Cheers,
> Jeff Clune
>
> Digital Evolution Lab, M=
ichigan State University
>
> jclune@...
>
>> From: Kenneth Stanley <kst=
anley@...>
>> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.=
com>
>> Date: Wed, 15 Oct 2008 17:33:38 -0000
>> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com"=
 <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>> Subject: [neat] Re: Population sizes
>>
>> I hav=
en't seen any explicit studies on population size in NEAT
>> specifically, =
but there have been such studies for genetic algorithms
>> in general. I th=
ink Kenneth De Jong's textbook, "Evolutionary
>> Computation: A Unified Per=
spective" examines it.
>>
>> However, of course as people have pointed out =
in NEAT it's not just a
>> question of a healthy population but of healthy =
species, since each
>> species is like its own little population. In other =
words, the
>> species need enough internal diversity to drive their own
>> =
explorations. My own rule of thumb has been a minimum of 15 members
>> per =
species (on average) to keep them healthy. I'm sure 30 is even
>> safer.
>>=

>> Another thing to note is that the population size you need can vary
>> =
wildly by problem and it can be surprising. For pole balancing, it
>> turns=
 out that you can solve it fastest with a minuscule population of
>> size u=
nder 20 total (that's for the whole population!). That is
>> because smalle=
r populations are greedier (they concentrate resources
>> on a small part o=
f the search space) and apparently pole balancing
>> benefits greatly from =
greedy search. However, that is a specific
>> property of pole balancing an=
d I would not expect it to carry over to
>> more significant domains. Surel=
y in some domains having a population
>> over 1000 would lead to the most i=
nteresting results, if only you can
>> afford the luxury of the added compu=
tational cost of a large population.
>>
>> ken
>>
>> --- In neat@yahoogroup=
s.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>>>
>>> That's funny. I heard the sam=
e thing about 1000...that in ecology if a
>>> species gets under 1000 they =
really start to worry about the
>> population. I
>>> don't think 30 will do=
 it, but I confess I have not read any
>> literature on
>>> it recently.
>>=
>
>>> Anyone else know?
>>>
>>> Has anyone done any studies with NEAT on po=
p size to see what the
>> plot of
>>> pop size vs. fitness looks like?
>>>
=
>>>
>>>
>>>
>>> Cheers,
>>> Jeff Clune
>>>
>>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michi=
gan State University

>>>> From: Matt Sim=
merson <m.simmerson@...>

roups.com>

>>>> To: "neat@yahoog=
roups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>>> Subject: [neat] Re: Population sizes=

>>>>
>>>> I typically use around 150, but set the target species to 5 usin=
g a
>>>> changing compatability threshold. This gives a rough specie size o=
f
>>>> 30. I read somewhere, and I can't remember where, some article about=

>>>> Highland cattle having to have a breeding population of 30 to make th=
e
>>>> gene pool viable.
>>>>
>>>> I guess its also a trade off with time a=
lso. I am evolving Torcs
>>>> controllers for Julain Togelius' CIG 2008 com=
mpetition. Each
>>>> controller takes around 4 seconds to evaluate. If I ha=
d a pop of over
>>>> 1000, it would take a long time for my poor laptop to =
finish each
>> epoch.
>>>>
>>>> Cheers
>>>>
>>>> Matt
>>>>
>>>> --- In neat=
@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
>>>>>
>>>>> Hello all-
>>>>>
=
>>>>> What population sizes to you typically use for NEAT?
>>>>>
>>>>> We h=
ave done experiments in the Avida digital evolution platform that
>>>>> sug=
gest that below 1,000 org drift starts to play a role. But a lot
>>>> of th=
e
>>>>> HyperNEAT papers use pop sizes of 150 or so. My guess is that the
>=
>>> diversity
>>>>> preserving measure ('speciation') and elitism help make=
 smaller
>>>> populations
>>>>> effective, but I was wondering if anyone ha=
s looked at the effects of
>>>>> population size in NEAT in an effort to pr=
ovide a *rough but general*
>>>>> suggestion as to how big to make the popu=
lations in NEAT.
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>> Cheers,
>>>>> Jeff Clune
